question: A child has a splenic mass with a mediastinal mass. He appears pale, has red eyes and suffers from recurrent infections. Possible diagnosis is -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i.e., Acute Lymphoblastic leukemia o The age group and symptoms of the child are consistent with Acute Lymphoblastic leukemia AcuteLymphoblastic leukemiao Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) encompasses a group of neoplasms composed of immature, precursor B or T (Pre-T) lymphocytes referred to as lymphoblast.Clinical manifestations of ALLo Symptoms related to depression of normal marrow function.o An accumulation of neoplastic blast cells in the bone marrow suppresses normal hematopoisis by physical crowding and competition for growth factorso This results in : - Anemia - Fatigue, palloro Neutropenia - Infection, intermittent fevero Thrombocytopenia - Bleeding, petechiae, ecchymoses, epistaxis.o These are the most common sign & symptoms.o Bone pain and tenderness resulting from marrow expansion and infiltration of the subperiosteum.o Generalized lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly and hepatomegaly Caused by neoplastic infiltration of these tissues. More common in ALL than AML.o Symptoms related to compression of large mediastinal vessels or airway In Pre-T ALL of thymuso CNS manifestation Due to meningeal involvement. -Headache, vomiting, nerve palsies. More common in ALL than in AML.o Testicular involvement is also more common in ALL than in AML.

question: Good prognostic factor for AML are all except -
exp: Ans. is 'c' i.e., Acute Mega karyoblastic leukemia Good Prognostic factors for children with AMLo Prognostic factors are not quite as important in predicting outcome or in guiding treatment for AML as they* are for ALL.o Age at diagnosis: Children younger than age 2.o Initial white blood cell (WBC) count; Children with AML whose WBC count is less than 100,000 cells per cubic millimeter Down syndrome: Children with Down syndrome who develop AML tend to have a good outlook.o Subtype of AML: the acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) M3 subtype tends to have a good outlook while undifferentiated AML (MO) and acute megakaryoblast ic leukemia (M7) are harder to treat.o Chromosome changes: Children with leukemia cell translocations between chromosomes 15 and 17 or between 8 and 21, or with an inversion (rearrangement) of chromosome 16 have a better chance of being cured.o Response to treatment: Children whose leukemia responds quickly to treatment.o Body weight: Children within the normal weight range tend to do better than children who are underweight or overweight.
